instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> on the bench that isn't charging the battery, but runs fine from the battery. No liquid damage, was dropped on its side and hasn't charged since then. Tried a known working DC board but same result. I tested with an el cheapo charger and it does charge, just not with my bench psu. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> has continuity to the Magsafe and voltages seem good (1 - 3.45v   4 - 3.42v   5  - 3.42v). Given that it charges fine with the shitty charger, is this a leakage issue like some of the previous forum threads? If so, how do I test to find the culprit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Did you test with 85W charger for sure?
Machine works good with charger alone (no battery)?
Magsafe light stays amber?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: It's a genuine 85w charger. Machine runs without batt and light stays amber. Tried a brand new battery to rule that out too and the new battery wouldn't charge either.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
What's the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage, w/ and w/o battery connected?
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> levels, with battery connected (page 45).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with the battery is 12.5v when powered off, but it falls to 10.8v when I power on the machine. On charger without battery it's steady 12.5v. <SIGNAL>SMC_CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> is 0.049v and <SIGNAL>DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> is 1.05v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
1V at <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> means a lot of current consumed from charger.
Is that value in off state with battery connected?
Post exact resistance between pins 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: With battery <SIGNAL>DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> is 1.05v and without it is 0.24v. Resistance between  pins 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is 20.9 ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: 1.05V in off state???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: Correct, both of those measurements were taken while the board is plugged in to power but turned off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Then is strange; <SIGNAL>SMC_CHGR_BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> should increase too.
1V at <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> denotes approx 2.5A through <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
If board is off, almost all current should go through <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>.
In such case, <SIGNAL>SMC_CHGR_BMON_ISENSE</SIGNAL> should be approx 0.45V; you've reported less than 0.05V there.

0.24V at <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_ISENSE</SIGNAL> is also too much for off state without battery.
It suppose approx 0.6A consumption.
You may need to change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Post its voltages; 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 25, 27.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: Went to go take measurements and the first few were 0v and I noticed I lost my green light and PSU now pulls 0 amps. Did some checking and I seem to be missing <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U7001</CHIP>, but I still have PP3V42 going in. Is that a good sign <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is pooched?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: So you cannot measure above mentioned pins without Magsafe light???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
"3 - 0.762v"
Bad value!
Check <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>, possibly open/corroded.
Also remove <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: Just to check my understanding (hopefully I'm learning lol) pin 3 receives its power from <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> which is what also powers <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> through <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>. So that should be the same voltage as my power supply is outputting then, not next to nothing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: Yeah, <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>/11 divisor creates ACIN signal for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>/11 looked like they had some gunk around them, so I replaced both from a donor - same voltage as before. Removed <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR>, voltage dropped to 0.006v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Do you have correct voltage at pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>?
If you've changed the resistors with correct values, then change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and check again the voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Did have correct voltage at <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> pin 1, double checked the values of resistors. I went ahead and replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, got green light back. When booted board still does not charge though. Here are my <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages now:

1 - 0.004v
2- 17.90v
3 - 4.32v
9 - 0.293v
12 - 3.4v
13 - 3.4v
14 - 3.305v
15 - 0.080v
17 - 12.58v
19 - 5.513v
20 - 5.522v
25 - 17.50v
27 - 18.33v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with both charger and battery connected.
12.58V is good without battery.
Also post resistance between pins 17/18 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: Voltage with battery is fluctuating between 11.3 and 11.7v (tested with brand new battery). Resistance of pins 17/18 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is 3.3 ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Magsafe light flashing green/amber with battery?
Check now <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with only battery (no charger).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
I do get green to amber with the battery plugged in. Voltages with only battery, no charger: 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 11.26v 
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.43v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Amber light comes on without battery too.
You've said to get fluctuating <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with charger and battery connected at same time.
I asked to check if Magsafe light color fluctuates then too.

Does the board turn on with battery alone?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Oh I see, sorry. No, the light doesn't fluctuate, it stays solid amber after turning from green.

The board does not turn on with battery alone, and while running with battery and charger if I disconnect charger the laptop shuts off immediately.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Can you get a known good battery for test?
Be aware, new chinese doesn't mean known good!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: I have 2 in my stock right now that I've tried, I get mine from Mobilesentrix so I'm hoping they're decent quality

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
It is not same as known good.
I saw so many strange behaviors of bad new batteries, that you cannot imagine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: Very weird. Reassembled everything with the original battery the and it's charging properly now. Gonna test it over the weekend to make sure it's consistent but I think this is solved?! Thanks so much for the help! I feel like I'm slowly figuring things out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message: Update: Genuine charger stops working after 15-20 seconds of charging, but a knock off charger charges fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Charging
threads.message:
Machine works with original charger, only stops charging battery?
Try another original 85W Magsafe 2 charger.
